results.title: Atomic power and the U.S.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
This film examines the United States’ nuclear energy programme for the production of electric power; five types of nuclear reactors designed by U.S. Government laboratories and American industries; nuclear plants operated and financed by private industry. Atomic fuel and technical skills developed by intensive research in the United States are available to other countries through international agreement. No other credits available.

results.title: Training men for the atomic age
results.creator_credit: Hearst Metrotone and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Atoms for Peace”
The training program in nuclear physics for foreign scientists sponsored by the US Atomic Energy Commission. Shows activities at the University of Pennsylvania, Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies, International School of Nuclear Science and Engineering at La Grange, Illinois, and construction of a nuclear reactor at Shippingport, Pennsylvania.

results.title: Scientific advancement
results.creator_credit: James Blake Cahoon and Information Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes the progress made in the production of atomic electric power. Historically interesting for the 1956 prediction that atomic power will be used to eliminate poverty and war.

results.title: Agriculture, industry and power
results.creator_credit: United States Information Agency and Warner-Pathe News
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes research into the practical and beneficial uses of atomic energy and radioactive materials in agricultural and industrial production. Highlights Gama rays being used to develop better crop species, radioactive cobalt assisting fertiliser research, atomic energy detecting flaws in castings, checking wear on piston rings and, food preservation, synthetic fuel and electric power applications.

results.title: Introducing the atom
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
An overall introduction to the series. Provides a basic explanation of atomic energy. Animated sequences demonstrate the make-up, function, formation and controlled chain reaction. It shows the atomic pile at Los Alamos and the preparation and storage of radio-isotopes at Oak Ridge. Touches on the uses of atomic materials in medical research, agriculture and industry. The film ends with excerpts from President Eisenhower’s speech before the United Nations, emphasising America’s hopes and desires for International control of atomic energy dedicated to human welfare everywhere.

results.title: Working together
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Regional and international co-operation of scientists ad governments in the development of peaceful se of atomic energy; and some of the achievements of this co-operation, sch as the flow of isotopes from one country to another, the transfer of fissionable materials for research purposes, and the establishment of international centres for atomic research. From the series “Atoms for peace”.

results.title: Medicine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Shows uses of atomic materials in medical research and diagnosis; illustrates, through a sequence involving a brain tumour, the use of radioactive materials as tracers in the detection and location of disease; and describes atomic research in the treatment of hyperthyroidism, cancer and arteriosclerosis.

results.title: Atomic physics: an historical approach
results.brief_description: A five part series designed for use in agencies teaching advanced physics. This series traces the development of atomic energy from when John Dalton forwarded his atomic energy theory in 1808. Through reconstruction and interviews, the scientists Dalton, Faraday, Rutherford, Cockcroft, Frisch and Einstein are introduced. Each part of the series is usable independently.

group_works.title: Neutron smashing: the discovery of the atom
The Nuclear structure of the atom

results.title: Neutron smashing: the discovery of the atom
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Atomic physics: an historical approach”.
This film shows various instruments used in research, and their diagrammatic explanations; from a very early machine for measuring ionisation, to an electric machine, built after 1932 in the Cavendish laboratory, used to bombard atoms. Includes a speech by Einstein, and an explanation of isotopes and the research leading up to this understanding. No credits available.
